awd_titl_txt: Tangible Programming Environment Targeted for Students who are Visually Impaired
awd_abstract_narration:
As computing has become integral to the practice of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM), the STEM+Computing program seeks to advance applied research integrating computational thinking and computing activities within disciplinary science, technology, engineering, and mathematics teaching and learning in early childhood education through high school (preK-12). There is currently no accessibility solution that allows blind and visually impaired learners use of the new highly visual programming languages that are ubiquitous and which are specifically designed to improve sighted students' engagement and ease of learning computer programming. The aim of this proposed project, by Virginia Commonwealth University and Smith-Kettlewell Institute, is to provide a new interface "tSCRATCH" for the programming environment to enable visually impaired students to be engaged in computation and computational thinking. This work has the potential to improve learning of computer programming for all students, but will particularly focus on providing equal and shared access to individuals who are visually impaired. The learning approach is to develop a non-visual interface for a learning application, Scratch, that takes into account the strengths and weaknesses of the haptic (physical) and auditory systems. The project will be evaluated by Praxis Associates, who will provide ongoing feedback on the project to the project team. 

This work has the potential to improve learning of computer programming for all students, but it will focus on providing access to individuals who are visually impaired. The approach is to develop a tangible, non-visual interface for Scratch that takes into account the strengths and weaknesses of the haptic and auditory systems. It will adapt a low-cost tactile tile concept to represent program commands, along with a grid surface and other organizational structures, to ensure that programs of moderate complexity can be created. A key aspect of the approach is to allow users to manipulate commands as a group to enable chunking (i.e., grouping into a whole) of information for ease of manipulation and cognitive understanding. Multi-media instructional material will be developed by experts in teaching students computer programming who are visually impaired. Further, this intervention will explore the possibility of tScratch to be used alongside of Scratch in mainstream classrooms by the use of the tScratch prototype in a computer camp type setting. The assessment of the intervention will consider the change in both blind and sighted students' ability to apply programming concepts, share in teamwork, views of each other, and views of computer science.

por.por_cntn:
The purpose of this project was to provide K-12 students who are blind or visually impaired equitable access to learning how to program by providing assistive technology to allow them to learn in the classroom, coding camps and after school clubs alongside, but independent, of their sighted peers.  We chose to do this through the development of a non-visual interface for the Scratch programming language, which is ubiquitous in K-12 classrooms and conscientiously designed  to increase engagement and lower the barriers to programming for sighted students. The nonvisual interface was designed to be accessible for both individuals with visual disabilities and those without, so that students with visual disabilities are able to also participate equitably in team projects.

A critical component of the approach was to translate key aspects of Scratch that increased engagement and lowered hurdles to programming for sighted students to the haptic domain, which is accessible by all students with visual disabilities. To do so, it was necessary to consider the significant differences between how haptics and vision process information to avoid adding new barriers due to these differences. Visual design techniques for low vision were also used in tandem to ensure access for students who may still use their residual vision, as well as sighted students. Components of the system were developed with stakeholder feedback, including two full design iterations for the main components of the system with objective user testing involving individuals who were blind or visually impaired.

The characteristics of the Scratch programming language which were incorporated into the prototype developed were: (1) the use of code construction through action, (2) the ability to co-construct code with others, (3) a straightforward environment, (4) a reduction in the need to struggle with syntax, and (5) tinkerability (by allowing the workspace to operate in a manner similar to a physical workbench). In our nonvisual code editor, programs are constructed by connecting physical code blocks (Figure 1), the sizes of which were chosen to construct programs of moderate size within arms reach of a sitting student. The raised profile on the code blocks provide visual and haptic orientation and identification information. The reciprocal tab/notch pairs on connecting blocks embed the programming syntax needed to program correctly: blocks that fit together form valid computer code, those that do not fit together are unable to create code. Magnets are used within the tab/notch connections to provide more salient feedback about the validity of the syntax and allow users to easily move chunks of code, facilitating tinkerability. Expandable telescoping tubing in both the horizontal and vertical directions allow expansion of parameter "slots" to incorporate larger or multi-line commands.

The code blocks are constructed on a work surface that provides specially designed haptic feedback to facilitate programming tasks and communication with the teacher and fellow students. The code block palette is formed with a storage drawer organization system from which the physical code blocks assembles are drawn. Code blocks and code segments may also be left on the workspace for reuse. The program code is executed by a mobile robot acting as a Scratch sprite (Figure 2). The mobile robot is designed with a "hat" on which the user can rest their hand to allow non-visual following of the robot.  Haptic cues on both the robot and the background surface are used to facilitate the accurate determination of movement distances, and to create different story and game scenarios.

Pilot testing of the complete system with seven middle school and high school students who were blind or visually impaired was performed through multiple offerings of a 2-day camp for students with visual disabilities at VCU. Each camp simulated a classroom setting with 1-2 students . A hands-on learning curriculum, consisting of lecture notes, accessible multi-media support materials and accessible quizzes, was created for this purpose.  Participating students were found to use the system as expected and were enthusiastic about the camp. Improvements for subsequent design iterations were noted.

The intention of this project was to develop accessible technology to increase STEM learning opportunities, particularly in computer science, for K-12 students with visual disabilities. It was particularly designed to follow the example of the Scratch programming language to allow more students to learn programming that otherwise may not have succeeded. This is intended to encourage and contribute to preparing these students for entering into rewarding STEM careers. This will also increase diversity in STEM fields, bringing in new ideas to help keep the U.S.'s competitive edge in science and technology. Learning approaches that provide multisensory information have also been found to be beneficial to the students without visual disabilities.
